texts.definition: Quests that are based around a companion to a player.
markups: <style="Definition">Quests that are based around a companion to a player.</style>

The goals of some game are expressed as diegetic missions and called quests. A special case of these are <style="CurrentLink">Companion Quests</style> which focus not on players but on the NPCs that are followers to the player.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> are examples of games that have <style="CurrentLink">Companion Quests</style>.

The main reason for introducing <style="CurrentLink">Companion Quests</style> in games is to provide <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> for <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> that players can explore. The actual design simply relies on creating <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> for <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>. Specific for them is how players should become aware of the quest opportunities since the <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> typically already are following the players when the <style="CurrentLink">Companion Quests</style> should become possible. Specific events or coming to locations are examples of what can trigger the start of <style="CurrentLink">Companion Quests</style>.

As stated above, <style="CurrentLink">Companion Quests</style> are used to create <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. As such, the pattern is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Narration%20Patterns">Narration Pattern</link></style> besides a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Goal%20Patterns">Goal Pattern</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Companion Quests</style> often consist of <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style> that tie together several individual <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>. This either to pace the <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> with other <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> in a game or because the whole story arc for the <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> would become too long for one <style="Link"><link="quests">Quest</link></style>.

The outcome of <style="CurrentLink">Companion Quests</style> can be used to influence which particular ending players should get. In doing so, the pattern can affect <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Multiple%20Endings">Multiple Endings</link></style> and can stress that gameplay <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Companion Quests</style> are <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>, or more specifically <style="Link"><link="sidequests">Sidequests</link></style> which makes them into <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>. It can give the <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> they focus on an <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style>.
